title: Quiz 3: Common Clinical Tachycardias
topicName: Cardiology Cardiac Electrophysiology  A Visual Guide for Nurses
description: Assessment on mechanisms, diagnosis, and ablation of AVNRT, AVRT, Atrial Flutter, AF, and VT.

questions.question: What is the typical circuit for 'Slow-Fast' AVNRT?

options.text: Antegrade Slow Pathway, Retrograde Fast Pathway
Antegrade Fast Pathway, Retrograde Slow Pathway
Antegrade Slow Pathway, Retrograde Slow Pathway
Antegrade Fast Pathway, Retrograde Fast Pathway

questions.explanation: Typical AVNRT is 'Slow-Fast': signals go DOWN the Slow pathway (causing a long AH interval) and UP the Fast pathway (causing a short VA interval/echo).
questions.hint: Think about the PR interval (AH) vs the RP interval.

questions.question: An accessory pathway that conducts only retrogradely (from V to A) and does not show a delta wave is called a ___BLANK___ pathway.
questions.explanation: Since it doesn't pre-excite the ventricle, its presence is 'concealed' on the surface ECG during sinus rhythm.
questions.hint: It is hidden from the surface ECG.

questions.question: Identify the critical target structure for ablation of Typical Atrial Flutter.

richContent.content: Anatomy Hint: It is the isthmus of tissue located between the Inferior Vena Cava and the Tricuspid Valve annulus.

options.text: Cavo-Tricuspid Isthmus (CTI)
Crista Terminalis
Pulmonary Vein Antrum
Coronary Sinus Ostium

questions.explanation: The CTI is the critical slow conduction zone for the typical atrial flutter macro-reentrant circuit.
questions.hint: Look for the structure connecting the IVC and TV.

questions.question: Which finding confirms 'Bidirectional Block' across the CTI after flutter ablation?

options.text: Pacing medial to the line produces late lateral activation, AND pacing lateral produces late medial activation
Pacing medial to the line produces early lateral activation
Termination of atrial flutter during ablation
Reduced electrogram amplitude on the ablation line

questions.explanation: Bidirectional block means the signal cannot cross the line; it must go all the way around the tricuspid annulus, resulting in late activation on the other side regardless of pacing direction (medial-to-lateral or lateral-to-medial).
questions.hint: The signal has to take the 'long way' around.

questions.question: Order the sequence of events in the initiation of AVNRT.

items.text: Block in the Fast Pathway (due to refractory period)
Conduction proceeds down the Slow Pathway (long AH)
Retrograde conduction up the recovered Fast Pathway

questions.explanation: A PAC finds the Fast pathway refractory, travels down the Slow (jump), allowing the Fast to recover and conduct retrogradely, initiating the loop.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of 'Entrance Block' during Pulmonary Vein Isolation? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Disappearance of PV potentials on the Lasso catheter during atrial pacing
Dissociated potentials (PV firing independently of atrium)
Failure to capture the atrium when pacing the PV
Termination of AF

questions.explanation: Entrance block means signals can't get IN. Pacing the atrium and seeing no PV potentials, or seeing the PV doing its own thing (dissociated), confirms this. Failure to capture atrium from PV proves EXIT block.
questions.hint: Focus on signals entering the vein from the atrium.

questions.question: Match the VT mapping strategy to its best clinical use case.
questions.explanation: Activation/Entrainment require stable VT. Pace mapping mimics morphology. Substrate modification targets scar/channels without needing sustained VT.
questions.hint: Consider stability and mechanism (focal vs reentrant).

questions.question: What is the primary target for ablation in Focal Atrial Tachycardia?

options.text: The site of earliest atrial activation
The Cavo-Tricuspid Isthmus
The AV Node Slow Pathway
The Pulmonary Veins

questions.explanation: Focal AT originates from a point source. Mapping seeks the spot where the atrial signal is earliest relative to the P-wave or reference.

questions.question: In 'Antidromic' AVRT, the QRS complex is narrow.
questions.explanation: False. Antidromic AVRT conducts down the accessory pathway (pre-excitation) and up the node. Because ventricular activation is fully via the AP, the QRS is wide (maximally pre-excited).
questions.hint: Does it use the normal conduction system to activate the ventricle?

questions.question: What does a 'Split A' signify during CTI ablation?

options.text: Separation of wavefronts on either side of the ablation line
Dissociated Pulmonary Vein potentials
Double firing of the atrium
Successful termination of flutter

questions.explanation: As the isthmus is blocked, the electrode records activation from one side (early) and then waits for the signal to go all the way around the annulus to the other side (late), splitting the potential.
questions.hint: Think about two signals arriving at different times.

questions.question: Which feature best distinguishes Focal VT from Reentrant VT?

options.text: Focal VT radiates from a point source; Reentrant VT uses a circuit around scar
Focal VT is always faster
Reentrant VT always has a narrow QRS
Focal VT cannot be ablated

questions.explanation: Focal VT spreads out from a single spot (centrifugal). Reentrant VT spins around an obstacle (like scar), often having an identifiable isthmus.
questions.hint: Think about the mechanism of activation spread.

questions.question: Where does the 'Slow Pathway' typically insert anatomically?

options.text: Inferiorly, near the Coronary Sinus os
Superiorly, near the His bundle
Lateral Right Atrium
Left Atrial Septum

questions.explanation: The slow pathway is an inferior extension of the AV node, anatomically located between the CS os and the tricuspid annulus (Triangle of Koch).

questions.question: A His-refractory PVC that terminates SVT without conducting to the atrium proves the mechanism is AVRT.
questions.explanation: True. If the PVC can't go up the AV node (His refractory) and doesn't go up an AP (no atrial capture) but STOPS the tachycardia, it must have invaded the ventricular limb of an AVRT circuit.
questions.hint: Only AVRT requires the ventricle for the circuit to continue.
